message_1: What is the standard enthalpy of formation of methane (CH4) given the following combustion reaction: CH4(g) + 2O2(g) -> CO2(g) + 2H2O(l), with the heat of combustion of methane being -890.4 kJ/mol?
message_2:
To find the standard enthalpy of formation of methane (ΔHf°), we need to use the following equation:

ΔHf°(CH4) = ΔHcomb°(CH4) + ΔHf°(CO2) + 2ΔHf°(H2O) - 2ΔHf°(O2)

We know the heat of combustion of methane (ΔHcomb°(CH4)) is -890.4 kJ/mol. We also know the standard enthalpy of formation of O2 is 0 kJ/mol since it is an element in its standard state. We need to find the standard enthalpy of formation for CO2 and H2O.

The standard enthalpy of formation for CO2 (ΔHf°(CO2)) is -393.5 kJ/mol, and for H2O (ΔHf°(H2O)) is -285.8 kJ/mol.

Now we can plug these values into the equation:

ΔHf°(CH4) = -890.4 kJ/mol + (-393.5 kJ/mol) + 2(-285.8 kJ/mol) - 2(0 kJ/mol)

ΔHf°(CH4) = -890.4 kJ/mol + (-393.5 kJ/mol) - 571.6 kJ/mol

ΔHf°(CH4) = -1855.5 kJ/mol + 571.6 kJ/mol

ΔHf°(CH4) = -1283.9 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy of formation of methane (CH4) is -1283.9 kJ/mol.
